Child Labor on Farms About 150,000 children, most of them migrants, work long hours on the nation's farms, prompting a call for new labor laws.

Revival for Catholic Schools In Roman Catholic schools, it's easier to find non-Catholic students than to find priests and nuns teaching. But with the help of vouchers and and the faltering reputation of public education the schools are making a comeback.
Chicano Radio's Future Radio stations and D.J.'s who have long been an unofficial voice for their Southern California community look for their place as the community changes.

Watergate's Top Secret Who was Deep Throat, who helped bring down President Richard Nixon in 1974? Leonard Garment, Nixon's last White House counsel, says he knows; in any case, he tells. Michael Oreskes reviews ''In Search of Deep Throat.''
The Other Antitrust Trial Fed up with Coke's aggressive marketing tactics, rival distributors sued -- and won. A glimpse at the soda wars.
Sydney Olympic Guide The city prepares to entertain 300,000 guests a day, with world-class sports arenas, a major arts festival, stellar restaurants and lively antiques shops.
Vanilla Conventions The Republican convention may have been bland, but George W. Bush got his message across. Now the question is whether Al Gore can do the same.
